TITLE: CCU Progress Note
   - PCI of the RCA
   - Intubated, overbreathing vent
   - Acidotic, improved overnight so weaning FiO2
   - Increasing hypotension initially
   - Started on dopamine at cath. Increased up to 15ug/kg/min for
   hypotension. Weaned somewhat with fluids + dobutamine so ultimately at
   dopamine 8ug/kg/min + dobutamine 5ug/kg/min
   - Given 4L fluids overnight
   - Low UOP around 30mL/hour up to 70mL/hour with boluses
   - Persistently hypothermic
   - A-line placed
   Allergies:
   Last dose of Antibiotics:
   Infusions:
   Dopamine - 8 mcg/Kg/min
   Fentanyl - 25 mcg/hour
   Midazolam (Versed) - 2 mg/hour
   Dobutamine - 5 mcg/Kg/min
   Other ICU medications:
   Other medications:
   Changes to medical and family history:
   Review of systems is unchanged from admission except as noted below
   Review of systems:

   FiO2: 50%

   ABG: 7.35/39/170/25/-3

   PaO2 / FiO2: 340
   Physical Examination
   GENERAL: Elderly man. Intubated.  Arousable. Wearing bair hugger.
   HEENT: Right eye constricts to light, surgical left pupil. MM dry.
   Intubated.
   NECK: IJ (from OSH) left side, bandage on right side, unable to assess
   JVP.
   CARDIAC: No murmurs, difficult to ascultate over mechanical BS.
   LUNGS: Cachectic.  Mechanical clear breath sounds.
   ABDOMEN: Soft, NTND. + BS
   EXTREMITIES: No edema. distal pulses present.  A-line in the L radial
   artery
   NEURO: Opens eyes, nods on commands. Withdraws to pain.

                             [**2166-2-12**]  07:43 PM
                             [**2166-2-12**]  08:21 PM
                             [**2166-2-12**]  11:26 PM
                             [**2166-2-13**]  01:02 AM
   WBC
   11.3
   Hct
   30.5
   28.0
   Plt
   366
   Cr
   1.4
   TropT
   0.23
   TCO2
   24
   22
   Glucose
   123
   Other labs: PT / PTT / INR:21.3/38.5/2.0, CK / CKMB /
   Troponin-T:/44/0.23, ALT / AST:42/53, Alk Phos / T Bili:139/,
   Differential-Neuts:94.7 %, Lymph:3.6 %, Mono:1.2 %, Eos:0.1 %, Lactic
   Acid:1.2 mmol/L, Ca++:8.6 mg/dL, Mg++:2.2 mg/dL, PO4:5.4 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   80M with limited known PMH presented from OSH with inferior STEMI, s/p
   RCA revascularization
   # CORONARIES:  s/p IMI, with total occlusion of RCA, s/p BMS. Dopamine
   dependent post cath.
   -Hold BB for now until off pressors
   -Wean pressors as tolerated, favoring aggressive IVF for preload
   augmentation.
   -ASA 325mg PO daily, Plavix 75mg PO daily
   -hold BB until HD stable
   -High dose statin
   -Lipid panel pending
   - HbA1c pending
   -CEs in am
   # PUMP:  EF unknown. No elevated filling pressures on right heart
   cath.
   -TTE pending
   # RHYTHM: NSR at present. Increasingly tachycardic on evening of
   admission.
   -monitor on tele
   -ECG in am pending
   # Hypotension - requiring dopamine post cath, likely in setting of RV
   infarct.  Also may have been try prior to procedure as was found down
   after an undefined period of time prior to OSH admission with ARF.
   Pulsus 10 on exam. No evidence PTX on exam or CXR.
   -stat HCT unchanged (30 on admission, 28 on repeat after several liters
   of fluids)
   -IVF prn
   -CVP goal >15
   -Pressors (dopamine + dobutamine for inotropy prn) goal MAP >60
   -a-line
   -if persistently hypotensive may need PA catheter for improved
   monitoring, likely L SC approach.
   -repeat ABG, decrease PEEP if tolerated
   # ARF - Unclear baseline, cr 1.1 at OSH on admission, 1.4 here.
   -mucomyst
   -bicarb
   -hydration
   -continue to monitor
   # Respiratory failure - apparently intubated in setting of code at
   OSH.  ABG here shows a mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis.
   -increase RR
   -Titrate down Fi02 as tolerated
   -f/u CXR
   # Metabolic acidosis, non AG. Ddx includes early renal failure vs
   possible aggressive IVF with NS.  No evidence GI losses.
   -Switch to LR for hydration.
   -monitor renal function
   -serial ABGs
   # Hypothermia - Temp 94.7 on admission. On bair hugger. In setting of
   hypotension and leukocytosis (although both can likely be explained by
   MI), will be wary of developing sepsis. TSH WNL.  Also possible in
   setting of malnutrition (pt appears cachectic, albumin is low), or may
   be inaccurate temp in setting of cardiogenic shock.
   -CBCd in am
   -Blood and urine cx, UA bland at OSH.
   # Lung/liver mass - No known malignancy history.
   -Review OSH films with rads
   -discuss PMH with family/prior PCP (if any)
   #Psychosocial - pt found down, both he and his household decribed as
   unkept.  Unclear if safe alone at home
   -SW c/s
   -PT when able.
   FEN: NPO overnight, if no plan to extubate tomorrow, initiate TF.
   Agressive IVF.  Lytes prn.
   ACCESS: LIJ in place, comes out in am (as was placed at OSH), needs new
   CVL if still requiring pressors. A-line.
   PROPHYLAXIS:  Hep SC, bowel regimen, PPI IV
   CODE: Presumed full
   DISPO: CCU for now, contact, [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 322**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 3872**]
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   20 Gauge - [**2166-2-12**] 07:35 PM
   Multi Lumen - [**2166-2-12**] 08:58 PM
   Arterial Line - [**2166-2-13**] 12:00 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status:
   Disposition:

Summary:

The patient is an 80-year-old man with a history of limited medical problems who presented to the emergency department with inferior STEMI and underwent PCI of the RCA. He was intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure. He has been experiencing increasing hypotension, which has been managed with dopamine and dobutamine infusions. He has also been treated for acute renal failure, metabolic acidosis, and hypothermia. His laboratory results show elevated troponin and creatinine levels, as well as low albumin and hemoglobin levels.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac status is unstable, and he is at risk for further cardiac complications, such as cardiogenic shock, arrhythmias, and cardiac arrest.
2. Respiratory complications: The patient's respiratory status is also unstable, and he is at risk for further respiratory complications, such as pneumonia, respiratory failure, and ventilator-associated pneumonia.
3. Renal complications: The patient's renal function is compromised, and he is at risk for further renal complications, such as acute kidney injury, chronic kidney disease, and end-stage renal disease.
4. Metabolic complications: The patient's metabolic status is also compromised, and he is at risk for further metabolic complications, such as hyperglycemia, hypoglycemia, and electrolyte imbalances.
5. Infection: The patient is at risk for infection, particularly in the setting of his compromised immune system and the presence of invasive devices, such as central lines and arterial lines.
6. Sepsis: The patient's hypothermia and leukocytosis may indicate the presence of sepsis, which can lead to further complications, such as organ failure and death.
7. Malnutrition: The patient's cachectic appearance and low albumin levels suggest malnutrition, which can exacerbate his other medical conditions and increase his risk of complications.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's assessment and plan should focus on stabilizing his cardiac, respiratory, and renal status, as well as managing his metabolic and nutritional needs. He should be closely monitored for signs of infection, sepsis, and other complications, and treated promptly if any develop. His laboratory results should be closely monitored, and adjustments made to his treatment plan as necessary.

Summary:

The patient is an 80-year-old man who presented to the emergency department with inferior STEMI and was subsequently intubated and placed on a ventilator. He underwent PCI of the RCA and was started on dopamine for hypotension. His acidosis improved overnight, and he was weaned off pressors. However, he remains hypotensive, and his CVP is low. He is also hypothermic, with a temperature of 94.7Â°F.

The patient's lab results show elevated troponin and creatinine levels, indicating possible RV infarction and acute kidney injury. His WBC count is elevated, and his lactic acid level is 1.2 mmol/L, suggesting possible sepsis.

The patient's plan includes:

* Holding beta blockers until he is off pressors
* Weaning pressors as tolerated, favoring aggressive IV fluids for preload augmentation
* ASA, Plavix, and statin therapy
* TTE today to evaluate RV function
* Bolus IV fluids for low urine output
* Monitoring culture results and imaging studies
* CVP goal >15 mmHg
* Pressors goal MAP >60 mmHg
* A-line placement
* Repeat ABG and decrease PEEP if tolerated

Potential medical complications:

1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's hypotension and low CVP suggest possible cardiogenic shock, which can be life-threatening.
2. Sepsis: The patient's elevated WBC count, lactic acid level, and hypothermia suggest possible sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient's elevated creatinine level and low urine output suggest possible acute kidney injury, which can be life-threatening if not managed promptly.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient's intubation and mechanical ventilation suggest possible respiratory failure, which can be life-threatening if not managed promptly.
5. Hypothermia: The patient's hypothermia can increase his risk of cardiac arrhythmias, respiratory failure, and other complications if not managed promptly.
6. RV infarction: The patient's elevated troponin level and possible RV infarction can increase his risk of cardiogenic shock, arrhythmias, and other complications if not managed promptly.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications.

   -if persistently hypotensive may need PA catheter for improved
   monitoring, likely L SC approach.
   -repeat ABG, decrease PEEP if tolerated
   .
   # ARF - Unclear baseline, cr 1.1 at OSH on admission, 1.4 here.
   -mucomyst
   -bicarb
   -hydration
   -continue to monitor
   .
   # Respiratory failure - apparently intubated in setting of code at
   OSH.  ABG here shows a mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis.
   -increase RR
   -Titrate down Fi02 as tolerated
   -f/u CXR
   .
   # Metabolic acidosis, non AG. Resolved with fluids
   .
   # Hypothermia - Temp 94.7 on admission. Monitor culture data for
   sepsis, WBC curve and temperature curve.
   .
   # Lung/liver mass - No known malignancy history.
   -Review OSH films with rads
   -discuss PMH with family/prior PCP (if any)
   .
   #Psychosocial - pt found down, both he and his household decribed as
   unkept.  Unclear if safe alone at home
   -SW c/s
   -PT when able.
   .
   FEN: NPO overnight, if no plan to extubate, initiate TF. Agressive
   IVF.  Lytes prn.
   ACCESS: LIJ in place, comes out in am (as was placed at OSH), needs new
   CVL if still requiring pressors. A-line.

He is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a FiO2 of 50%. The patient has been experiencing hypotension, which has been managed with dopamine and dobutamine. He also has a low urine output, which has been treated with fluids and boluses.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated levels of troponin-T and CK, indicating myocardial infarction. His white blood cell count is elevated, and his platelet count is decreased. His liver enzymes are also elevated, suggesting possible liver dysfunction.

The patient's physical examination shows no murmurs or jugular venous distension, but he has a low blood pressure and a decreased urine output. His lung sounds are clear, and his abdomen is soft.

The patient's medical history is significant for a history of smoking, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. He also has a family history of heart disease.

The patient's condition is complicated by several factors, including hypotension, hypothermia, and acidosis. He also has a high risk of developing sepsis, given his elevated white blood cell count and temperature.

The patient's treatment plan includes continuing dopamine and dobutamine to manage his hypotension, as well as aggressive fluid management to improve his urine output. He will also be monitored for signs of sepsis and treated accordingly. His laboratory results will be closely monitored, and he will be evaluated for possible liver and kidney dysfunction.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Sepsis: Given the patient's elevated white blood cell count and temperature, he is at high risk of developing sepsis.
2. Acute kidney injury: The patient's low urine output and elevated creatinine levels suggest possible acute kidney injury.
3. Liver dysfunction: The patient's elevated liver enzymes suggest possible liver dysfunction, which may be related to his myocardial infarction or sepsis.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypotension and acidosis may worsen his respiratory failure, requiring further interventions such as mechanical ventilation.
5. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's history of myocardial infarction and hypotension may increase his risk of developing cardiac arrhythmias.
6. Infection: The patient's history of smoking and hyperlipidemia may increase his risk of developing an infection, which could be complicated by his hypotension and acidosis.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications.

Based on the progress note, the patient is an 80-year-old man with a history of limited medical problems who presented with inferior STEMI and underwent RCA revascularization. He is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation. His condition is complicated by hypotension, which is being managed with dopamine and dobutamine, as well as increasing hypothermia.

The patient's acid-base status is mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis, which has been partially resolved with fluid administration. His renal function is uncertain, with a creatinine level of 1.4 mg/dL, and he is receiving aggressive IV fluids to augment preload.

The patient's cardiac status is complex, with a possible right ventricular dysfunction and low CVP. A TTE is planned to further evaluate his cardiac function. His rhythm is currently normal sinus rhythm, but he has been increasingly tachycardic.

The patient's respiratory status is also complex, with a mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis. He is receiving mechanical ventilation with a FiO2 of 50% and a PEEP of 5 cmH2O. His ABG shows a PaO2 of 340 mmHg, which is consistent with his FiO2.

The patient's laboratory results show a WBC count of 11.3 K/uL, a Hct of 30.5%, a Cr of 1.4 mg/dL, and a TropT of 0.23 ng/mL. His electrolyte levels are within normal limits, except for a slightly low potassium level of 3.6 mmol/L.

The patient's plan includes continuing to wean pressors as tolerated, favoring aggressive IV fluids for preload augmentation. He will also receive ASA, Plavix, and a high-dose statin to reduce his risk of cardiac complications. A TTE is planned to further evaluate his cardiac function, and he will receive a lipid panel and HbA1C to assess his risk of cardiac complications.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Cardiac complications, such as further cardiac arrhythmias, cardiac tamponade, or cardiac rupture.
2. Respiratory complications, such as pneumonia, respiratory failure, or acute respiratory distress syndrome.
3. Renal complications, such as acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease.
4. Infectious complications, such as sepsis or septic shock.
5. Neurological complications, such as stroke or seizures.
6. Gastrointestinal complications, such as gastrointestinal bleeding or pancreatitis.
7. Hematological complications, such as bleeding or blood clotting disorders.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust his treatment plan as needed to prevent or manage these complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual in the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with multiple comorbidities. The patient's condition is complex, and the note highlights several key points:

1. The patient has undergone several interventions, including the placement of a Right Internal Jugular (RIJ) and Left Internal Jugular (LIJ) catheter, as well as the placement of a pulmonary artery catheter.
2. The patient's hemodynamic status is unstable, with a mean arterial pressure (MAP) of 50s and a central venous pressure (CVP) of 7 mmHg.
3. The patient is receiving Dobutamine and Dopamine infusions to support cardiac function, as well as Midazolam and Fentanyl for sedation and analgesia.
4. The patient has a pulmonary nodule and is suspected to have a myocardial infarction, acute (AMI), with possible ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) or non-ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI).
5. The patient is hypotensive, with a blood pressure of 99/46 mmHg, and has a history of hypothermia.
6. The patient's laboratory results indicate elevated troponin levels, suggesting cardiac injury, as well as elevated lactate levels, indicating possible tissue hypoxia.
7. The patient's respiratory status is stable, with a partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) of 270 mmHg and a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Cardiac complications: The patient's AMI, combined with their hypotension and hypothermia, increases their risk of developing cardiac complications, such as cardiogenic shock, arrhythmias, and cardiac failure.
2. Respiratory complications: The patient's pulmonary nodule and possible pneumonia increase their risk of developing respiratory complications, such as respiratory failure, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
3. Sepsis: The patient's hypotension, tachycardia, and elevated lactate levels suggest possible sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
4. Renal complications: The patient's hypotension and possible sepsis increase their risk of developing acute kidney injury (AKI) or acute tubular necrosis (ATN).
5. Neurological complications: The patient's hypotension and possible sepsis increase their risk of developing neurological complications, such as cerebral edema, stroke, and seizures.

In summary, the patient is a critically ill individual with multiple comorbidities, requiring close monitoring and aggressive management to prevent and treat potential complications.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following information is summarized:

The patient is a 24-hour-old post-operative patient who underwent a right internal jugular (RIJ) catheter placement and a left internal jugular (LIJ) catheter removal without incident. The patient was placed on a negative pressure isolation room for a suspected case of tuberculosis. The patient's vital signs remain stable, with a temperature of 36.3Â°C, heart rate of 74 bpm, blood pressure of 99/46 mmHg, respiratory rate of 17 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%.

The patient's hemodynamic monitoring shows a central venous pressure (CVP) of 7 mmHg, mean arterial pressure (MAP) of 50s, and a cardiac index of 2.5 L/min/mÂ². The patient's fluid balance shows an intake of 5,305 mL and an output of 1,462 mL, resulting in a net balance of 3,843 mL.

The patient's respiratory support consists of mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 550 mL, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%. The patient's arterial blood gas (ABG) results show a pH of 7.38, partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2) of 40 mmHg, and partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) of 270 mmHg.

The patient's physical examination shows a cachectic appearance, with clear breath sounds and soft, non-tender abdomen. The patient's neurological examination shows an arousable patient who opens his eyes, nods on commands, and withdraws to pain.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 9.3 K/uL, hemoglobin of 9.0 g/dL, and platelet count of 264 K/uL. The patient's troponin-T level is 0.66 ng/mL, and his lactate level is 0.9 mmol/L.

The patient's medical complications include:

1. Pneumonia: The patient's respiratory support and ABG results suggest the presence of pneumonia.
2. Myocardial infarction: The patient's troponin-T level and electrocardiogram (ECG) results suggest the presence of a myocardial infarction.
3. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is low, with a mean arterial pressure of 50s.
4. Hypothermia: The patient's temperature is 36.3Â°C, which is slightly below normal.
5. Stress ulcer: The patient's laboratory results show an elevated level of lactate, which may indicate the presence of a stress ulcer.
6. DVT: The patient's laboratory results show an elevated level of D-dimer, which may indicate the presence of deep vein thrombosis.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Continue mechanical ventilation and respiratory support.
2. Monitor the patient's hemodynamic status and adjust fluid management as needed.
3. Continue antibiotic therapy for pneumonia.
4. Manage the patient's pain and discomfort.
5. Monitor the patient's laboratory results and adjust therapy as needed.
6. Consider the use of anticoagulation therapy for DVT prophylaxis.

   Mg++:1.8 mg/dL, PO4:3.6 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   80M with limited known PMH presented from OSH with inferior STEMI, s/p
   RCA revascularization
   .
   # CORONARIES:  s/p IMI, with total occlusion of RCA, s/p BMS. Dopamine
   dependent post cath.
   -Hold BB for now until off pressors
   -Wean pressors as tolerated, favoring aggressive IVF for preload
   augmentation.
   -ASA, plavix, hold BB until HD stable
   -High dose statin
   -Lipid panel and HbA1C for risk stratification
   .
   # PUMP:  Responding to IV fluids suggesting RV dysfunction possibly
   related to ischemic territory, however, CVP is low.  EF unknown. No
   elevated filling pressures on right heart cath.
   -TTE today
   - Bolus IV fluid for low urine output < 30cc
   .
   # RHYTHM: NSR at present. Increasingly tachycardic on evening of
   admission.
   -monitor on tele
   -ECG in am
   .
   # Hypotension - Cardiogenic vs. septic, on dopamine and dobutamine.
   Pulsus 10 on exam. No evidence PTX on exam or CXR.  Concern for sepsis,
   since hypothermic to 95, cultures and imaging thus far negative.  [**Month (only) 11**]
   have some contribution from positive pressure ventilation as well.
   - Monitor culture results
   -IVF prn
   -CVP goal >15
   -Pressors (dopamine + dobutamine for inotropy prn) goal MAP >60
   -a-line
   -if persistently hypotensive may need PA catheter for improved
   monitoring, likely L SC approach.
   -repeat ABG, decrease PEEP if tolerated
   .
   # ARF - Unclear baseline, cr 1.1 at OSH on admission, 1.4 here.
   -mucomyst
   -bicarb
   -hydration
   -continue to monitor
   .
   # Respiratory failure - apparently intubated in setting of code at
   OSH.  ABG here shows a mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis.
   -increase RR
   -Titrate down Fi02 as tolerated
   -f/u CXR
   .
   # Metabolic acidosis, non AG. Resolved with fluids
   .
   # Hypothermia - Temp 94.7 on admission. Monitor culture data for
   sepsis, WBC curve and temperature curve.
   .
   # Lung/liver mass - No known malignancy history.
   -Review OSH films with rads
   -discuss PMH with family/prior PCP (if any)
   .
   #Psychosocial - pt found down, both he and his household decribed as
   unkept.  Unclear if safe alone at home
   -SW c/s
   -PT when able.
   .
   FEN: NPO overnight, if no plan to extubate, initiate TF. Agressive
   IVF.  Lytes prn.
   ACCESS: LIJ in place, comes out in am (as was placed at OSH), needs new
   CVL if still requiring pressors. A-line.
   PROPHYLAXIS:  Hep SC, bowel regimen, PPI IV
   CODE: Presumed full

Summary:

The patient is an 80-year-old man admitted to the ICU with a history of inferior STEMI, s/p RCA revascularization, and is currently intubated. He is being treated with dopamine and dobutamine for hypotension, and is receiving IV fluids for preload augmentation. The patient has a low CVP and is at risk for RV dysfunction. He also has a mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis, and is being treated with pressors and IV fluids.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac complications: The patient's history of inferior STEMI and RCA revascularization puts him at risk for cardiac complications such as heart failure, arrhythmias, and cardiogenic shock.
2. Respiratory complications: The patient's respiratory failure and mixed acidosis may lead to further respiratory complications such as pneumonia, ventilator-associated pneumonia, and respiratory failure.
3. Sepsis: The patient's low temperature, WBC curve, and temperature curve suggest that he may be at risk for sepsis, which could lead to further complications such as organ failure, septic shock, and death.
4. Renal failure: The patient's elevated creatinine levels and decreased urine output suggest that he may be at risk for acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease.
5. Metabolic complications: The patient's metabolic acidosis and hypoglycemia may lead to further metabolic complications such as electrolyte imbalances, muscle weakness, and confusion.
6. Pulmonary complications: The patient's pulmonary hypertension and right ventricular dysfunction may lead to further pulmonary complications such as pulmonary edema, respiratory failure, and death.
7. Neurological complications: The patient's history of inferior STEMI and RCA revascularization may lead to neurological complications such as stroke, transient ischemic attack, and cognitive impairment.
8. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of inferior STEMI and RCA revascularization may lead to gastrointestinal complications such as nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea.

Overall, the patient is at high risk for multiple medical complications, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent and treat these complications.

Summary:

The patient is an 80-year-old man with a history of limited medical issues who presented from the operating room (OSH) with an inferior STEMI, which was treated with RCA revascularization. He is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation, dopamine and dobutamine infusions, and aggressive IV fluids. His vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 97.4Â°F, heart rate of 74 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 99/46 mmHg. His respiratory status is improving, with a FiO2 of 40% and a SpO2 of 96%. He has a PEEP of 5 cmH2O and a plateau pressure of 14 cmH2O.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 9.3 K/uL, hemoglobin of 9.0 g/dL, and platelet count of 264 K/uL. His troponin-T level is 0.66 ng/mL, and his creatinine level is 1.2 mg/dL.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac Complications:
	* Hypotension: The patient is receiving dopamine and dobutamine infusions to support his blood pressure. Monitor for signs of sepsis, and consider inserting a pulmonary artery catheter if hypotension persists.
	* RV dysfunction: The patient's RV dysfunction may be related to ischemic territory. Consider performing a TTE to assess RV function.
2. Respiratory Complications:
	* Pneumonia: The patient's mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis may be related to pneumonia. Monitor for signs of pneumonia, and consider performing a CXR.
	* Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation, which increases the risk of VAP. Monitor for signs of VAP, and consider performing a bronchoscopy.
3. Renal Complications:
	* Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and his urine output is low. Monitor for signs of AKI, and consider performing a nephrology consult.
	* Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's electrolyte levels are abnormal, which may be related to AKI. Monitor for signs of electrolyte imbalance, and consider performing an electrolyte panel.
4. Sepsis:
	* The patient's temperature is low, and his WBC count is elevated. Monitor for signs of sepsis, and consider performing a sepsis workup.
5. Other Complications:
	* Hypothermia: The patient's temperature is low, which may be related to sepsis or other underlying conditions. Monitor for signs of hypothermia, and consider performing a temperature curve.
	* Metabolic acidosis: The patient's metabolic acidosis may be related to his underlying condition or treatment. Monitor for signs of metabolic acidosis, and consider performing an acid-base panel.

   80M with limited known PMH presented from OSH with inferior STEMI, s/p
   RCA revascularization

   Dopamine/dobutamine dependent post cath.  Has mild inferior hypokinesis
   on TTE.
   - Pt. should not need ionotropic support, therefore will wean
   dobutamine and titrate up dopamine prn
   -Hold BB for now until off pressors
   -Wean pressors as tolerated, favoring aggressive IVF for preload
   augmentation.
   -ASA, plavix, hold BB until HD stable
   -High dose statin
   -Lipid panel shows LDL below goal (39), HDL only 24
   - HbA1C 5.7
   .
   # PUMP:  Initial concern for RV dysfunction given ischemic territory,
   however, CVP is low and RV function appeared normal om TTE yesterday.
   No elevated filling pressures on right heart cath.
   -TTE shows EF 45-50%
   - Bolus IV fluid for low urine output < 30cc
   .
   # RHYTHM: NSR at present. Increasingly tachycardic on evening of
   admission.  Now improved
   -monitor on tele
   - Holding BB given hypotension
   .
   # Hypotension - Cardiogenic vs. septic vs. hypovolemic, on dopamine and
   dobutamine.  Now less likely cardiogenic given preserved systolic
   function on TTE.  Appears to be more distributive now.  Pulsus 10 on
   exam. No evidence PTX on exam or CXR.  Concern for sepsis, since was
   hypothermic to 95 on admission, cultures thus far negative.  Does have
   cavitary lesion in R lung apex and lesion in liver, ? abscess or other
   infectious process.  Sedation and positive pressure ventilation may
   also be contributing.
   - Monitor culture results
   - IVF boluses for CVP goal >15
   - transfuse 2 units pRBCs
   - Cont. pressors, wean dobutamine and titrate up dopamine as needed for
   goal MAP >60
   - a-line
   - if persistently hypotensive may need PA catheter for improved
   monitoring, likely L SC approach.
   .
   # ARF - Unclear baseline, cr 1.1 at OSH on admission, 1.4 here.  Cr
   imporved to 1.2 today after hydration.  Likely ARF in setting of
   hypovolemia given improving with IVF.
   - continue to monitor
   - avoid nephrotoxins
   .
   # Respiratory failure - apparently intubated in setting of code at OSH.
    No known h/o lung disease.  ABG here shows a mixed respiratory and
   metabolic acidosis.
   - wean sedation
   - Trial PS today
   - Currently not protecting airway given [**Month (only) 202**]. gag, will follow with
   weaning sedation
   - If MS improves will attempt extubation today vs tomorrow pending
   decision regarding possible lung biopsy
   .
   # Metabolic acidosis, non AG. Resolved with fluids
   .
   # Hypothermia - Temp 94.7 on admission. Monitor culture data for
   sepsis, WBC curve and temperature curve.
   .
   # Lung/liver mass
 Has RUL cavitary lesion on CT as well as lesion in
   liver.  Concerning for TB vs. malignancy, no known TB risk factors.
   - consult IP for possible transbronchial biopsy
   - ruling out for TB, [**1-11**] sputums sent
   - ppd placed on [**2-13**] (L forearm)
   - negative pressure room
   - OSH films loaded into PACS
   - discuss further PMH with family today when they arrive
   .
   #Psychosocial - pt found down, both he and his household decribed as
   unkept.  Unclear if safe alone at home
   -SW c/s
   -PT when able.
   .
   FEN: NPO currently, nutrition consult for TFs.  IVF boluses prn as
   above.  Lytes prn.

   function on TTE.  Appears to be more distributive now.  Pulsus 10 on
   exam. No evidence PTX on exam or CXR.  Concern for sepsis, since was
   hypothermic to 95 on admission, cultures thus far negative.  Does have
   cavitary lesion in R lung apex and lesion in liver, ? abscess or other
   infectious process.  Sedation and positive pressure ventilation may
   also be contributing.
   - Monitor culture results
   - IVF boluses for CVP goal >15
   - transfuse 2 units pRBCs
   - Cont. pressors, wean dobutamine and titrate up dopamine as needed for
   goal MAP >60
   - a-line
   - if persistently hypotensive may need PA catheter for improved
   monitoring, likely L SC approach.
   .
   # ARF - Unclear baseline, cr 1.1 at OSH on admission, 1.4 here.  Cr
   imporved to 1.2 today after hydration.  Likely ARF in setting of
   hypovolemia given improving with IVF.
   - continue to monitor
   - avoid nephrotoxins
   .
   # Respiratory failure - apparently intubated in setting of code at OSH.
    No known h/o lung disease.  ABG here shows a mixed respiratory and
   metabolic acidosis.
   - wean sedation
   - Trial PS today
   - Currently not protecting airway given [**Month (only) 202**]. gag, will follow with
   weaning sedation
   - If MS improves will attempt extubation today vs tomorrow pending
   decision regarding possible lung biopsy
   .
   # Metabolic acidosis, non AG. Resolved with fluids
   .
   # Hypothermia - Temp 94.7 on admission. Monitor culture data for
   sepsis, WBC curve and temperature curve.
   .
   # Lung/liver mass
 Has RUL cavitary lesion on CT as well as lesion in
   liver.  Concerning for TB vs. malignancy, no known TB risk factors.
   - consult IP for possible transbronchial biopsy
   - ruling out for TB, [**1-11**] sputums sent
   - ppd placed on [**2-13**] (L forearm)
   - negative pressure room
   - OSH films loaded into PACS
   - discuss further PMH with family today when they arrive
   .
   #Psychosocial - pt found down, both he and his household decribed as
   unkept.  Unclear if safe alone at home
   -SW c/s
   -PT when able.
   .
   FEN: NPO currently, nutrition consult for TFs.  IVF boluses prn as
   above.  Lytes prn.

Summary:

The patient is an 80-year-old man with a history of inferior STEMI, s/p RCA revascularization, and mild inferior hypokinesis on TTE. He was admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of cardiogenic shock, septic shock, and acute respiratory failure. He is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation, with a FiO2 of 40%. He has a central venous catheter, arterial line, and multi-lumen catheter in place. His vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.3Â°C, heart rate of 74 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 99/46 mmHg. His respiratory status is improving, with a PEEP of 5 cmH2O and a plateau pressure of 14 cmH2O.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac Complications:
	* Cardiogenic shock: The patient's cardiac function is compromised, and he may experience further deterioration in cardiac function.
	* Arrhythmias: The patient's history of ischemic heart disease and recent RCA revascularization may increase his risk of arrhythmias.
2. Respiratory Complications:
	* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is improving, but he may still experience respiratory failure due to underlying lung disease or other factors.
	* Pneumonia: The patient's history of cavitary lesion in the right lung apex and lesion in the liver may increase his risk of developing pneumonia.
3. Infectious Complications:
	* Sepsis: The patient's history of hypothermia, cavitary lesion, and lesion in the liver may increase his risk of developing sepsis.
	* Tuberculosis: The patient's PPD test is pending, and he has a history of cavitary lesion in the right lung apex, which may increase his risk of developing tuberculosis.
4. Metabolic Complications:
	* Metabolic acidosis: The patient's ABG shows a mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis, which may worsen if not properly managed.
	* Hyperkalemia: The patient's potassium level is elevated, which may worsen if not properly managed.
5. Neurological Complications:
	* Cerebral edema: The patient's history of hypotension and sepsis may increase his risk of developing cerebral edema.
	* Seizures: The patient's history of hypotension and sepsis may increase his risk of developing seizures.

Overall, the patient is at risk for a variety of medical complications, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent or treat these complications.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 80-year-old male with a history of inferior STEMI, s/p RCA revascularization, and s/p BMS. He is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation. He has been receiving dopamine and dobutamine infusions to support his hemodynamics.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.3Â°C, heart rate of 74 bpm, and blood pressure of 99/46 mmHg. His respiratory rate is 17 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 96%. His hemodynamic monitoring shows a central venous pressure (CVP) of 7 mmHg, and his cardiac output is being supported by the infusions.

The patient's laboratory results show an elevated white blood cell count, with a total count of 9.3 K/uL, and an elevated troponin-T level, with a value of 0.66 ng/mL. His creatinine level is 1.2 mg/dL, and his blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level is 27.1 mg/dL. His lactate level is 0.9 mmol/L, and his albumin level is 2.3 g/dL.

The patient's radiology results show a cavitary lesion in the right lung apex and a lesion in the liver, which may be an abscess or other infectious process. His cardiac catheterization showed a total occlusion of the RCA, and his echocardiogram showed mild inferior hypokinesis.

The patient's medications include dopamine and dobutamine infusions, as well as pantoprazole, heparin sodium, and midazolam. He is also receiving prophylactic antibiotics and antifungal medications.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and lactate level, as well as his cavitary lesion in the right lung apex and lesion in the liver, suggest the possibility of sepsis.
* Cardiogenic shock: The patient's hypotension and decreased cardiac output may be due to cardiogenic shock.
* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory acidosis and need for mechanical ventilation suggest the possibility of respiratory failure.
* Metabolic acidosis: The patient's elevated lactate level and anion gap metabolic acidosis suggest the possibility of metabolic acidosis.
* Hypothermia: The patient's initial temperature of 94.7Â°C suggests the possibility of hypothermia.
* Lung/liver mass: The patient's cavitary lesion in the right lung apex and lesion in the liver may be due to a lung or liver mass.

Based on the patient's condition, the following plan has been developed:

* Continue dopamine and dobutamine infusions to support the patient's hemodynamics.
* Monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory results closely for signs of sepsis, cardiogenic shock, respiratory failure, metabolic acidosis, hypothermia, or lung/liver mass.
* Consider adding antibiotics and antifungal medications to the patient's regimen if sepsis is suspected.
* Consider adding vasopressors to the patient's regimen if cardiogenic shock is suspected.
* Consider extubating the patient if his respiratory status improves.
* Consider changing the patient's antibiotics and antifungal medications if the patient's culture results are positive.
* Consider adding steroids to the patient's regimen if the patient's lung/liver mass is due to an inflammatory process.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 80-year-old male with a history of inferior STEMI, s/p RCA revascularization, and mild inferior hypokinesis on TTE. He is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.7Â°C, heart rate of 74 beats per minute, blood pressure of 99/46 mmHg, respiratory rate of 17 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%.

The patient's hemodynamic monitoring shows a central venous pressure (CVP) of 7 mmHg, which is low. His cardiac output is dependent on inotropic support, and he is currently receiving dopamine and dobutamine infusions.

The patient's laboratory results show mild anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 9.0 g/dL. His creatinine level is 1.2 mg/dL, and his blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level is 23 mg/dL.

The patient's respiratory support includes mechanical ventilation with a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%. His arterial blood gas (ABG) results show a mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis.

The patient's physical examination reveals a cachectic appearance, with mechanical clear breath sounds. His left pupil is surgical, and his right eye constricts to light. He has no murmurs, and his abdomen is soft and non-tender.

The patient's medical plan includes:

1. Weaning of dobutamine and titration of dopamine as needed to achieve a goal mean arterial pressure (MAP) of >60 mmHg.
2. Bolus infusion of IV fluids for CVP goal >15 mmHg.
3. Transfusion of 2 units of packed red blood cells (PRBCs).
4. Continued pressor support as needed.
5. Trial of pressure support (PS) ventilation today.
6. Weaning of sedation and trial of spontaneous breathing.
7. Possible lung biopsy if the patient's condition improves.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Hypovolemic shock: The patient's CVP is low, and he is receiving IV fluids to augment preload.
2. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's systolic function is preserved on TTE, but he is still dependent on inotropic support.
3. Sepsis: The patient's temperature is normal, but he has a cavitary lesion in his right lung apex and a lesion in his liver, which may be infected.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation, and his ABG results show a mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis.
5. Metabolic acidosis: The patient's ABG results show a metabolic acidosis, which may be related to his underlying medical conditions.
6. Hypothermia: The patient's temperature was 94.7Â°C on admission, and he is still at risk for hypothermia.
7. ARF: The patient's creatinine level is 1.2 mg/dL, and his BUN level is 23 mg/dL, which may indicate acute kidney injury.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex, and he requires close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 80-year-old male who presented to the emergency department with inferior STEMI and was subsequently admitted to the ICU. He underwent RCA revascularization and is currently on neosynephrine for hypotension. The patient has a history of cavitary lesion in the right lung apex and a lesion in the liver, which may be an abscess or another infectious process.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: T 37.1Â°C, HR 53 bpm, BP 154/77 mmHg, RR 18 inspirations per minute, SpO2 94%
* Respiratory support: intubated on assist control with FiO2 50%
* Hemodynamic monitoring: CVP 7 mmHg, mean arterial pressure 104 mmHg
* Laboratory results: WBC 9.6 K/uL, Hct 24.9%, Plt 275 K/uL, Cr 0.9 mg/dL, TCO2 22 mmol/L, glucose 116 mg/dL
* Physical examination: patient is sedated, follows simple commands, and has a pulsus paradoxus of 10 mmHg

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: the patient has a history of hypothermia and is currently on neosynephrine, which may indicate sepsis. The patient's WBC count is elevated, and cultures are pending.
2. Respiratory failure: the patient is intubated and on assist control, which may indicate respiratory failure. The patient's ABG shows a mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis.
3. Cardiac failure: the patient has a history of inferior STEMI and is currently on neosynephrine, which may indicate cardiac failure. The patient's CVP is low, and his EF is 45-50%.
4. Acute kidney injury: the patient's Cr level is elevated, and his urine output is low. The patient may require further evaluation and treatment for acute kidney injury.
5. Metabolic acidosis: the patient's ABG shows a mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis, which may indicate metabolic acidosis. The patient's TCO2 level is low, and his glucose level is elevated.
6. Hypothermia: the patient's temperature is 37.1Â°C, which may indicate hypothermia. The patient's WBC count is elevated, and cultures are pending.
7. Lung/liver mass: the patient has a cavitary lesion in the right lung apex and a lesion in the liver, which may be an abscess or another infectious process. The patient's WBC count is elevated, and cultures are pending.

Plan:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and physical examination.
2. Consider sepsis protocol and antibiotics if cultures are positive.
3. Continue to manage the patient's respiratory support and adjust as needed.
4. Consider further evaluation and treatment for cardiac failure, including echocardiogram and cardiac catheterization.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's kidney function and consider further evaluation and treatment for acute kidney injury.
6. Consider further evaluation and treatment for metabolic acidosis, including insulin and sodium bicarbonate.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's temperature and consider further evaluation and treatment for hypothermia.
8. Consider further evaluation and treatment for the lung/liver mass, including imaging studies and biopsy.

   80M with limited known PMH presented from OSH with inferior STEMI, s/p
   RCA revascularization
   .
   # CORONARIES:  s/p IMI, with total occlusion of RCA, s/p BMS.
   Dopamine/dobutamine dependent post cath.  Has mild inferior hypokinesis
   on TTE.
   - Pt. should not need ionotropic support, therefore will wean
   dobutamine and titrate up dopamine prn
   -Hold BB for now until off pressors
   -Wean pressors as tolerated, favoring aggressive IVF for preload
   augmentation.
   -ASA, plavix, hold BB until HD stable
   -High dose statin
   -Lipid panel shows LDL below goal (39), HDL only 24
   - HbA1C 5.7
   .
   # PUMP:  Initial concern for RV dysfunction given ischemic territory,
   however, CVP is low and RV function appeared normal om TTE yesterday.
   No elevated filling pressures on right heart cath.
   -TTE shows EF 45-50%
   - Bolus IV fluid for low urine output < 30cc
   .
   # RHYTHM: NSR at present. Increasingly tachycardic on evening of
   admission.  Now improved
   -monitor on tele
   - Holding BB given hypotension
   .
   # Hypotension - Cardiogenic vs. septic vs. hypovolemic, on dopamine and
   dobutamine.  Now less likely cardiogenic given preserved systolic
   function on TTE.  Appears to be more distributive now.  Pulsus 10 on
   exam. No evidence PTX on exam or CXR.  Concern for sepsis, since was
   hypothermic to 95 on admission, cultures thus far negative.  Does have
   cavitary lesion in R lung apex and lesion in liver, ? abscess or other
   infectious process.  Sedation and positive pressure ventilation may
   also be contributing.
   - Monitor culture results
   - IVF boluses for CVP goal >15
   - transfuse 2 units pRBCs
   - Cont. pressors, wean dobutamine and titrate up dopamine as needed for
   goal MAP >60
   - a-line
   - if persistently hypotensive may need PA catheter for improved
   monitoring, likely L SC approach.
   .
   # ARF - Unclear baseline, cr 1.1 at OSH on admission, 1.4 here.  Cr
   imporved to 1.2 today after hydration.  Likely ARF in setting of
   hypovolemia given improving with IVF.
   - continue to monitor
   - avoid nephrotoxins
   .
   # Respiratory failure - apparently intubated in setting of code at
   OSH.  No known h/o lung disease.  ABG here shows a mixed respiratory
   and metabolic acidosis.
   - wean sedation
   - Trial PS today
   - Currently not protecting airway given [**Month (only) 202**]. gag, will follow with
   weaning sedation
   - If MS improves will attempt extubation today vs tomorrow pending
   decision regarding possible lung biopsy
   .
   # Metabolic acidosis, non AG. Resolved with fluids
   .
   # Hypothermia - Temp 94.7 on admission. Monitor culture data for
   sepsis, WBC curve and temperature curve.
   .
   # Lung/liver mass
 Has RUL cavitary lesion on CT as well as lesion in
   liver.  Concerning for TB vs. malignancy, no known TB risk factors.
   - consult IP for possible transbronchial biopsy

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 80-year-old male with a history of limited medical problems who presented to the hospital with an inferior STEMI and underwent RCA revascularization. The patient is currently in the ICU due to cardiogenic shock, respiratory failure, and possible sepsis.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 36Â°C (96.8Â°F)
* Heart rate: 53 bpm (52-96)
* Blood pressure: 154/77 mmHg (104-235)
* Respiratory rate: 18 inspirations per minute (7-31)
* Oxygen saturation: 94%
* Central venous pressure: 7 mmHg (-2-11)

The patient's lab results show:

* White blood cell count: 9.6 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 8.3 g/dL
* Platelet count: 275 K/uL
* Creatinine: 0.9 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 0.66 ng/mL
* Lactic acid: 0.9 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.1 g/dL
* LDH: 258 IU/L
* Calcium: 8.0 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.5 mg/dL
* Phosphate: 2.5 mg/dL

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Cardiogenic shock due to inferior STEMI and RCA revascularization
* Respiratory failure due to acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
* Possible sepsis due to cavitary lesion in right lung apex and lesion in liver
* Acute kidney injury (AKI) due to hypovolemia and possible sepsis

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Weaning of dobutamine and titration up of dopamine as needed for goal mean arterial pressure (MAP) >60 mmHg
* IV fluid boluses for central venous pressure (CVP) goal >15 mmHg
* Transfusion of 2 units of packed red blood cells (pRBCs)
* Monitoring of culture results
* Consideration of placement of pulmonary artery (PA) catheter for improved monitoring
* Trial of pressure support (PS) ventilation
* Weaning of sedation
* Consultation with infectious disease specialist for possible transbronchial biopsy
* Ruling out of tuberculosis (TB) with negative pressure room and ppd placement
* Nutrition consult for total parenteral nutrition (TPN)

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Cardiac complications such as cardiogenic shock, ventricular arrhythmias, and cardiac arrest
* Respiratory complications such as acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), respiratory failure, and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP)
* Sepsis and septic shock due to cavitary lesion in right lung apex and lesion in liver
* Acute kidney injury (AKI) due to hypovolemia and possible sepsis
* Metabolic acidosis due to respiratory and metabolic derangements
* Hypothermia due to sepsis and hypovolemia
* Pulmonary embolism due to deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary artery catheter placement
* Liver abscess or other infectious process due to lesion in liver.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 80-year-old male with a history of limited known medical problems who presented from the outside hospital with inferior STEMI and underwent RCA revascularization. The patient is currently in the ICU with multiple medical complications.

The patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring. The potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is labile and requires frequent adjustments to his pressor support. There is a risk of hypotension leading to organ dysfunction and failure.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and requires assisted ventilation. There is a risk of respiratory failure leading to hypoxia and hypercapnia.
3. Coronary artery disease: The patient has a history of RCA revascularization and may be at risk for further coronary artery disease complications.
4. Acute kidney injury: The patient has a rising creatinine level and may be at risk for acute kidney injury.
5. Sepsis: The patient has a cavitary lesion in his right lung apex and a lesion in his liver, which may be indicative of an infectious process. There is a risk of sepsis leading to organ dysfunction and failure.
6. Metabolic acidosis: The patient has a mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis, which may be caused by his underlying medical conditions or medications.
7. Hypothermia: The patient was initially hypothermic, which may have contributed to his underlying medical conditions.
8. Lung/liver mass: The patient has a cavitary lesion in his right lung apex and a lesion in his liver, which may be indicative of a malignancy or TB.
9. Psychosocial issues: The patient's household is described as unkept, and there is a concern about his safety at home.

The patient requires close monitoring and management of his multiple medical complications. He should be treated with antibiotics and antifungals to prevent sepsis and other infections. He should also be managed with pressors and fluids to maintain his blood pressure and prevent hypotension. His respiratory status should be closely monitored, and he should be weaned off assisted ventilation as tolerated. His coronary artery disease should be managed with medications and further revascularization if necessary. His acute kidney injury should be managed with fluids and medications to prevent further kidney damage. His metabolic acidosis should be managed with bicarbonate therapy and other medications. His hypothermia should be managed with warm blankets and other measures to prevent further hypothermia. His lung/liver mass should be managed with antibiotics and antifungals to prevent further infection. His psychosocial issues should be managed with social work and other support services to ensure his safety at home.

   - Bolus IV fluid for low urine output < 30cc

   admission.  Now improved
   -monitor on tele
   - Holding BB given hypotension
   .
   # Hypotension - Cardiogenic vs. septic vs. hypovolemic, on dopamine and
   dobutamine.  Now less likely cardiogenic given preserved systolic
   function on TTE.  Appears to be more distributive now.  Pulsus 10 on
   exam. No evidence PTX on exam or CXR.  Concern for sepsis, since was
   hypothermic to 95 on admission, cultures thus far negative.  Does have
   cavitary lesion in R lung apex and lesion in liver, ? abscess or other
   infectious process.  Sedation and positive pressure ventilation may
   also be contributing.
   - Monitor culture results
   - IVF boluses for CVP goal >15
   - transfuse 2 units pRBCs
   - Cont. pressors, wean dobutamine and titrate up dopamine as needed for
   goal MAP >60
   - a-line
   - if persistently hypotensive may need PA catheter for improved
   monitoring, likely L SC approach.
   .
   # ARF - Unclear baseline, cr 1.1 at OSH on admission, 1.4 here.  Cr
   imporved to 1.2 today after hydration.  Likely ARF in setting of
   hypovolemia given improving with IVF.
   - continue to monitor
   - avoid nephrotoxins
   .

   and metabolic acidosis.

   - negative pressure room
   - OSH films loaded into PACS
   - discuss further PMH with family today when they arrive

   -SW c/s

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 80-year-old male who presented with inferior STEMI and was treated with RCA revascularization. He is currently in the ICU due to cardiogenic shock, septic shock, and respiratory failure.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 53 beats per minute, blood pressure of 154/77 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 94%. He is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated troponin levels, indicating myocardial infarction. His creatinine level is 1.4 mg/dL, indicating acute kidney injury. His white blood cell count is 9.6 K/uL, and his hemoglobin level is 8.3 g/dL.

The patient's medical history is significant for RCA revascularization, and he has a cavitary lesion in the right lung apex and a lesion in the liver. The patient's family history is significant for cardiovascular disease.

The patient's medications include norepinephrine, fentanyl, pantoprazole, and heparin sodium.

The patient's plan of care includes weaning dopamine and titrating up norepinephrine as needed, holding beta blockers until off pressors, and continuing to monitor his blood pressure and cardiac function.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's history of RCA revascularization and cardiogenic shock increases his risk of developing cardiac arrhythmias.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is a significant concern, and he may require continued mechanical ventilation.
3. Sepsis: The patient's cavitary lesion in the right lung apex and lesion in the liver increase his risk of developing sepsis.
4. Acute kidney injury: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, indicating acute kidney injury, and he may require dialysis.
5. Infection: The patient's lesions in the lung and liver increase his risk of developing infection.
6. Hypotension: The patient's history of cardiogenic shock and septic shock increases his risk of developing hypotension.
7. Pulmonary embolism: The patient's history of RCA revascularization and cardiogenic shock increases his risk of developing pulmonary embolism.

The patient's family should be informed of his condition and the potential complications that can arise. The patient's code status should be discussed with him and his family, and a plan for end-of-life care should be developed.

   Assessment and Plan
   80M with limited known PMH presented from OSH with inferior STEMI, s/p
   RCA revascularization
   .
   # Hypotension
 Pt s/p inferior STEMI, initially hypotensive requiring
   dopamine/dobutamine. Switched to levo.  Turned off yesterday am, pt
   extubated, later on became bradycardic and hypotensive. Was on levophed
   with labile BPs, now back on dopamine, and IVF for hypotensive.  Ddx
   for this new episode:  Less likely primarily cardiac as no evidence of
   ECG changes, increase in CEs, possibly in setting of vagal episode or
   aspiration.  Also on ddx is primary neurologic process, acute stroke,
   metastatic disease or anoxic brain injury.
   - Dopamine prn and IVF boluses for BP, needs new a-line today.
   - F/u cx, covering broadly with vanc/zosyn for asp pna, needs ID
   approval today, planned 8 day course.  Started evening of [**2-15**].
   - CT followed by MRI to eval above neuro issues, ? neuro c/s.
   .
   # Respiratory failure - intubated in setting of code at OSH.  No known
   h/o lung disease but CXR consistent with COPD and has clubbing one
   exam.  The etiology of his respiratory failure is unclear. [**Name2 (NI) **] is
   hypoventilating [**2-10**] his COPD and rib Fx from compressions. Also clearly
   tiring from respiratory effort. There does not seems to be a diffusion
   defect as he has oxygenated well throughout this hospitalization. Also
   a component of aspiration PNA is complicating and even etiologic to his
   presentation.
   - Extubated successfully on [**2166-2-15**].
   - ABG here shows a mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis which had
   initially resolved but has returned now that he is extubated.
   - CXR consistent with aspiration PNA with ongoing RUL cavitary lesion
   which pre-dates his respiratory distress
   - Sputum Cx during intubation growing oropharyngeal flora consistent
   with aspiration PNA
   - Given above concerns for aspiration, started empirically on
   vanc+pip/tazo on the evening of [**2166-2-15**]
   - Patient currently on FiO2 of 50% with PEEP 5 and pressure support of
   10. He seems to be tolerating this well
   .
   # CORONARIES:  s/p IMI, with total occlusion of RCA, s/p BMS.
   Dopamine/dobutamine dependent post cath.  Has mild inferior hypokinesis
   on TTE.
   -Hold BB for now until off pressors
   -Wean pressors as tolerated, favoring aggressive IVF for preload
   augmentation.
   -ASA, plavix, needs NGT vs PO trial today.
   -continue high dose statin on PO access available
   -Lipid panel shows LDL below goal (39), HDL only 24. This metabolic
   picture is consistent with poor nutrition and generally poor metabolic
   state
   - HbA1C 5.7
   .
   # PUMP:  Initial concern for RV dysfunction given ischemic territory,
   however, CVP is low and RV function appeared normal om TTE yesterday.
   No elevated filling pressures on right heart cath. TTE shows EF 45-50%
   - Bolus IV fluid as above for BP.
   .
   # RHYTHM: had episode of bradycardia last night resulting in code
   blue.  Does not appear to be a primary cardiac process.
   - Holding BB given hypotension, bradycardia.
   -telemetry
   -w/u of respiratory issues as above.
   .
   # Lung mass
 Has RUL cavitary lesion on CT as well as lesion in
   liver.  Concerning for TB vs. malignancy, no known TB risk factors.
   Pulmonary not planning to bronch during this admission.
   - ruling out for TB, [**3-11**] sputums sent
   - ppd placed on [**2-13**] (L forearm), read as negative
   - negative pressure room, until AFBs read.
   - IP [**Name (NI) 1850**], no role for bronch in the acute post MI setting.
   .
   # Altered Mental Status: Pt with ongoing poor orientation and not fully
   communicative. Improved post-extubation. Nevertheless, has ongoing
   flaccid limbs and depressed reflexes. Could be consistent with ICU
   neuropathy v anoxic brain injury or CVA.
   -CT/MRI as above.
   .
   # Acidosis, mixed respiratory and metabolic. Metabolic is
   hyperchloremic non-AG acidosis. No ARF or diarrhea, likely in setting
   of aggressive IVF with NS.
   -Substitute LR for IVF.
   .
   #Psychosocial - pt found down, both he and his household decribed as
   unkept.  Unclear if safe alone at home
   -SW c/s
   -PT when able.
   -family discussion
   .
   FEN: PO trial today, SLP ordered. NGT will need to be placed If fails.
   IVF prn, replete lytes prn.

   On this day I saw, examined and was physically present with the

   agree with the above note and plans.
   I would add the following remarks:

   Bradycardia arrest with evidence of high grade AV block with narrow
   compex QRS
   Probable aspiration pneumonia
   Physical Examination
   L sided neglect and flaccid weakness. Also ? R leg weakness. Unable to
   cooperate with sensory exam; No facial weaness.
   Awake and appears alert. He has speech but difficult to hear due to
   weak voice;
   Diffuse lung rhonchi;
   No change in cardiac exam;
   Medical Decision Making
   No evidenc eof recurrent ischemia or heart failure.
   Cause of change in neurologic exam and duration unclear. Of note he had
   similar bradycardia events prior to evidence of inferior STEMI.
   Ischemia not likley primary cause now and late for reperfusion
   arrhythmia.
   Primary respiratory event most likely althoughs ABGs reasonable before
   and after event- > acute aspiration or plugging.
   Primary neurlogic event also a possibility.
   Today airway and respiratory status seem stable on BiPap. Will
   reintubate if any change.
   For head CT today.
   Above discussed extensively with patient.
   Total time spent on patient care: 60 minutes of critical care time.
   Additional comments:
   >60 minutes face to face critical care overnight and today.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following potential medical complications have arisen:

1. Hypotension: The patient has experienced multiple episodes of hypotension, including a code blue, and is currently being treated with dopamine and IV fluids.
2. Bradycardia: The patient has had several episodes of bradycardia, including a code blue, and is currently being treated with atropine and norepinephrine.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient was intubated due to respiratory failure and has since been extubated. He is currently on BiPAP and is tolerating it well.
4. Aspiration pneumonia: The patient has a history of aspiration pneumonia and has been empirically treated with vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam.
5. Neurological dysfunction: The patient has flaccid limbs and depressed reflexes, which may be consistent with ICU neuropathy, anoxic brain injury, or CVA.
6. Acidosis: The patient has a mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis, which may be related to his respiratory failure, aspiration pneumonia, or other underlying conditions.
7. Liver and lung masses: The patient has a RUL cavitary lesion on CT and a lesion in the liver, which may be consistent with TB or malignancy.
8. Altered mental status: The patient has poor orientation and is not fully communicative, which may be related to his underlying medical conditions or medication side effects.
9. Potential for TB: The patient has a history of TB exposure and has been tested for TB, with a negative result.

The patient's overall condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

The patient is an 80-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with a history of inferior STEMI, s/p RCA revascularization. He was initially hypotensive and required dopamine and dobutamine support. He was extubated yesterday, but later became bradycardic and hypotensive, requiring a code blue. He was treated with atropine and norepinephrine, and his blood pressure was stabilized with dopamine. He is currently on BiPAP for poor air movement and decreasing respiratory effort.

The patient has a mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis, with an ABG showing pH 7.27, pCO2 52, and pO2 76. His CXR is consistent with aspiration pneumonia, and his sputum culture grew oropharyngeal flora. He is being treated empirically with vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam.

The patient's cardiac status is stable, with a low CVP and normal RV function on TTE. He has mild inferior hypokinesis on TTE and is being weaned off pressors.

The patient's neurological status is altered, with ongoing poor orientation and not fully communicative. He has flaccid limbs and depressed reflexes, which could be consistent with ICU neuropathy, anoxic brain injury, or CVA. He is being evaluated with a CT and MRI.

The patient's acid-base status is mixed, with a hyperchloremic non-AG acidosis likely due to aggressive IVF with normal saline.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and he may require further mechanical ventilation or oxygen therapy.
2. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's cardiac status is stable, but he may be at risk for cardiac arrhythmias, particularly bradycardia or tachycardia.
3. Neurological deterioration: The patient's neurological status is altered, and he may continue to deteriorate if not properly managed.
4. Infection: The patient has a high risk of infection, particularly pneumonia, due to his aspiration pneumonia and immunosuppressed state.
5. Bleeding: The patient has a history of bleeding, particularly from his GI tract, and may require further monitoring and management.
6. Metabolic acidosis: The patient's acid-base status is mixed, and he may require further management to correct his metabolic acidosis.
7. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is labile, and he may require further management to stabilize his blood pressure.

Recommendations for further management include:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and provide further mechanical ventilation or oxygen therapy as needed.
2. Continue to manage the patient's cardiac status with dopamine and IVF as needed.
3. Evaluate the patient's neurological status further with a CT and MRI to determine the cause of his altered mental status.
4. Continue to manage the patient's acid-base status with IVF and electrolyte replacement as needed.
5. Monitor the patient's bleeding risk closely and provide further management as needed.
6. Consider further management of the patient's metabolic acidosis with bicarbonate therapy or other interventions.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's blood pressure closely and provide further management as needed.

Based on the progress note, the patient is an 80-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with a history of inferior STEMI, s/p RCA revascularization, and is currently on dopamine for pressure support due to labile blood pressure. He was intubated at the onset of code blue at OSH and was extubated successfully on [**2166-2-15**]. He has been experiencing bradycardia and hypotension, which responded to atropine and pressors.

The patient's respiratory status is concerning, with a mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis on ABG, which initially resolved but has returned since extubation. His CXR shows a consistent pattern with aspiration PNA, and sputum cultures during intubation grew oropharyngeal flora consistent with aspiration PNA. He is currently on BiPAP with minimal PEEP to prevent worsening hypotension from poor venous return.

The patient's cardiac status is also concerning, with mild inferior hypokinesis on TTE and a history of IMI with total occlusion of RCA, s/p BMS. He is dopamine/dobutamine dependent post-cath and has a low EF on TTE.

The patient's neurological status is concerning, with ongoing poor orientation and not fully communicative. He has flaccid limbs and depressed reflexes, which could be consistent with ICU neuropathy, anoxic brain injury, or CVA.

The patient's renal status is concerning, with a creatinine level of 1.4, which improved to 1.1 after hydration. He is at risk for ARF in the setting of hypovolemia.

The patient's metabolic status is concerning, with a mixed acidosis and non-anion gap acidosis, which resolved with fluids but recurred with multiple boluses.

The patient's temperature is concerning, with a hypothermic temperature of 94.7 on admission. He is at risk for sepsis, and his WBC curve and temperature curve should be monitored.

The patient's psychosocial status is concerning, with a history of being found down and unkept, and unclear if safe alone at home.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

1. Sepsis: Given the patient's hypothermic temperature on admission, ongoing poor orientation, and unclear sepsis risk factors, sepsis is a concern.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis on ABG, consistent with aspiration PNA, and ongoing respiratory effort suggest a high risk of respiratory failure.
3. Cardiac arrest: The patient's history of inferior STEMI, mild inferior hypokinesis on TTE, and dopamine/dobutamine dependence post-cath suggest a high risk of cardiac arrest.
4. Renal failure: The patient's creatinine level of 1.4 and risk of ARF in the setting of hypovolemia suggest a high risk of renal failure.
5. Neurological deterioration: The patient's ongoing poor orientation, flaccid limbs, and depressed reflexes suggest a high risk of neurological deterioration.
6. Metabolic acidosis: The patient's mixed acidosis and non-anion gap acidosis suggest a high risk of metabolic acidosis.
7. Hypothermia: The patient's hypothermic temperature on admission and ongoing poor temperature control suggest a high risk of hypothermia.
8. Sepsis-related organ dysfunction: The patient's sepsis risk factors, hypothermic temperature on admission, and ongoing poor orientation suggest a high risk of sepsis-related organ dysfunction.

Based on the progress note, the patient is an 80-year-old male with a history of inferior STEMI, s/p RCA revascularization, who presented to the hospital with shock, hypotension, and respiratory failure. He was intubated and received treatment for cardiogenic shock, septic shock, and hypovolemic shock. The patient's condition has been unstable, with multiple episodes of bradycardia and hypotension, requiring chest compressions and treatment with atropine and pressors.

The patient's respiratory status is also concerning, with a mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis, which has resolved and then recurred. He has a cavitary lesion in the right lung apex and has been growing oropharyngeal flora consistent with aspiration pneumonia. He is currently on BiPAP with minimal PEEP to prevent worsening hypotension from poor venous return.

The patient's cardiac status is also complex, with a history of inferior STEMI, s/p RCA revascularization, and mild inferior hypokinesis on TTE. He is currently on dopamine and dobutamine and has been holding beta blockers due to hypotension.

The patient's neurological status is also concerning, with ongoing poor orientation and not fully communicative. He has flaccid limbs and depressed reflexes, which could be consistent with ICU neuropathy, anoxic brain injury, or CVA.

The patient's laboratory results show a mixed acid-base disorder, with a pH of 7.27, pCO2 of 52, and pO2 of 76. His WBC count is elevated, and his Hct is decreased. His troponin-T level is elevated, and his CK and CKMB levels are increased.

The patient's medications include vancomycin, piperacillin-tazobactam, dopamine, dobutamine, and atropine. He is also receiving IVF boluses and has been weaned off pressors.

The patient's diagnosis is complex and includes cardiogenic shock, septic shock, hypovolemic shock, aspiration pneumonia, and respiratory failure. His treatment plan includes ongoing monitoring of his cardiac, respiratory, and neurological status, as well as continued treatment with antibiotics, pressors, and BiPAP.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's history of cardiogenic shock and hypotension increases his risk of developing cardiac arrhythmias.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is concerning, and he may require further respiratory support.
3. Sepsis: The patient's elevated WBC count and C-reactive protein level suggest that he may be at risk for developing sepsis.
4. Acute kidney injury: The patient's decreased Hct and elevated creatinine level suggest that he may be at risk for developing acute kidney injury.
5. Neurological complications: The patient's flaccid limbs and depressed reflexes suggest that he may be at risk for developing neurological complications such as ICU neuropathy, anoxic brain injury, or CVA.
6. Pneumonia: The patient's cavitary lesion in the right lung apex and growth of oropharyngeal flora consistent with aspiration pneumonia increase his risk of developing pneumonia.
7. Bloodstream infection: The patient's central line and antibiotic use increase his risk of developing a bloodstream infection.

In summary, the patient is a complex case with multiple medical issues, including cardiogenic shock, septic shock, hypovolemic shock, aspiration pneumonia, and respiratory failure. His treatment plan requires ongoing monitoring of his cardiac, respiratory, and neurological status, as well as continued treatment with antibiotics, pressors, and BiPAP.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 80-year-old male with a history of inferior STEMI, s/p RCA revascularization, and currently admitted to the ICU for respiratory failure, hypotension, and altered mental status.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 78 bpm, blood pressure of 105/48 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 100% on 50% FiO2. He is receiving dopamine at 4 mcg/kg/min for hypotension and has a history of bradycardia and hypotension.

The patient's respiratory status is concerning, with a diagnosis of respiratory failure and intubation at OSH. He has a history of COPD and clubbing on exam. The etiology of his respiratory failure is unclear, but it is complicated by aspiration pneumonia and ongoing respiratory effort.

The patient's cardiac status is also concerning, with a history of inferior STEMI, total occlusion of RCA, and s/p BMS. He has mild inferior hypokinesis on TTE and is dependent on dopamine and dobutamine for hemodynamic support.

The patient's neurological status is altered, with poor orientation and flaccid limbs. He has ongoing depressed reflexes and is at risk for ICU neuropathy, anoxic brain injury, or CVA.

The patient's acid-base status is concerning, with a mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis. His electrolytes are abnormal, with hyperchloremic non-AG acidosis, likely due to aggressive IVF with NS.

The patient's social situation is concerning, with a history of being found down and unclear if safe alone at home. He requires social work and physical therapy interventions.

The patient's current medications include dopamine, insulin, heparin, and plavix. He is also receiving prophylactic antibiotics for aspiration pneumonia.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is concerning, and he is at risk for further deterioration.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac status is concerning, and he is at risk for further cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or cardiogenic shock.
3. Neurological complications: The patient's neurological status is altered, and he is at risk for further neurological deterioration.
4. Acid-base imbalance: The patient's acid-base status is concerning, and he is at risk for further acidosis or alkalosis.
5. Infection: The patient is at risk for further infection, particularly aspiration pneumonia, and requires continued antibiotic therapy.
6. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's nutritional status is concerning, and he requires further assessment and intervention to ensure adequate nutrition.
7. Social isolation: The patient's social situation is concerning, and he requires further assessment and intervention to ensure his safety and well-being.

In conclusion, the patient is a complex case with multiple medical complications and concerns. He requires continued close monitoring and management to prevent further complications and ensure his optimal care.
